Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with this course compared to others you have taken was
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
How would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other F&ES courses you have taken?
Given the course objectives, the level of intellectual challenge of the material covered was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
How well did the knowledge, skills, and insights gained in this class align with your expectations
What are the strengths and weaknesses of the course and how could it be improved?
What advice would you give to a student considering taking this class
Comments_List: General overview of terms and concepts in sustainability strategy, very little practical skill-building or deeper insight
Basic corporate management framework.
Corporate environmental strategy and the drivers and limitations for companies trying to be more sustainable.
A brief overview of different corporate environmental and sustainability strategies. A number of management terms.

I developed a foundation on concepts regarding business and environment, such as sustainability as a competitive advantage, co-opetition, and creating shared value. I learned how to create a sustainability strategy for a startup.

Before taking the course, I didn't know much about corporate environmental management, and now I'm able to speak to the subject in an informed way. Through the course discussions and readings, I can give concrete examples of how environmental initiatives can reduce risk and create competitive advantage for businesses.
An overview of corporate strategy.

Honestly, not a lot was learned in this course besides a few buzzwords that I probably would have learned from reading the course text in my spare time. If you have any experience in CSR, this class is not for you as the material covered will be largely outdated and repetitive.
Some interesting application of key business ideas to interesting environmental problems through the case study homework assignments.

This class offers a crash course in CSR. It gives a breadth of knowledge from green finance, to LCA, to operations, to strategy and helps to prepare you for other courses focused on sustainable business. The projects also offer a real world challenge for teams to tackle, giving practical knowledge and experience into the realities of corporate sustainability in practice.
I had never taken a business school class, so I really feel like I learned a lot. I learned how to do business cases, work with a client, and work on a team. The readings were pretty solid.
I learned about different methods of corporate competition.  I also learned about supply chains.

Variety of different ways to think about the intersection between business practices and environmental concerns. Some specific business analysis approaches for understanding the challenges and possibilities of a company's present and future. Learned a number of good examples and cases that I can keep in mind as touchstones.

I developed an understanding of how to approach sustainability for a corporation, what are the benefits of developing sustainable companies and how to improve the company's performance. I learned in what way the private sector can influence the policies and regulations, and found this very interesting.

I gained an understanding of the process of implementing sustainability at the corporate level. I learned various approaches to corporate sustainability, gained an understanding of exemplary cases, and learned about barriers and challenges companies face to environmental management.
The business case for sustainability.
This class was very introductory. As someone with relevant work experience, I got little from this class.
CEMS is a new focus and is still being developed

A lot of great insight into basic business principles, CSR, competitive advantage, bottom of the pyramid, creating shared value -- concepts all very applicable for working on sustainability issues within corporations.
I developed an understanding for how to strategically implement a sustainability agenda in the corporate setting.
Learned about sustainable advantage, risks and reputation, eco-advantage, CSR vs CSV, green branding and marketing, sustainable investing and metrics, supply chains and industrial ecology.
Honestly, none come to mind.
This class was more useful for a strategic framework than for technical skills. It was a good introduction course to the terminology and themes of CSR.
A survey of topics that involve strategy related to environmental pressures facing businesses.

It was very disappointing. The class felt superficial, and I didn't learn much. I expected to get specific insights about real business decisions, but we only covered general principles, with nebulous practical implications, as evidenced by the scattered and disorganized term projects.
I think overall the course content is just not very insightful. We had a survey of many frameworks but never really dug deep into any of them. I don't feel like I gained any concrete skill.
Well.

I expected a more practical approach that treated more in-depth the challenges to make a profitable business and at the same time tackle sustainability. More study cases would have been very appreciated.

The class is very popular because it is one of the fewest that links environment and businesses. However, it gives a too brief overview of every topic. I was expecting to dive deeper in the strategies and info that concerns environmental management in corporations.
My expectations were to learn the theory and foundation for business and environment concepts. So I'd say my expectations aligned with the class.

For the most part, this course met my expectations. I understand how to speak about environmental topics in the business world, and have more hope for businesses to step up and help solve some of our environmental problems (where federal government is lacking leadership).
Seemed quite simplistic?

everything about this course was underwhelming and it was highly disappointing. I had high hope for this course as its a trendy and relevant topic for my course of studies, but this did not meet a single expectation.

I was very disappointed by the class. Much of what I learned was already taught in the SOM core. Environmental concepts were very basic for anyone with an environmental economics or management background.

This class aligned with my expectations well. It is a survey course offering a large breadth of information to ensure you have knowledge of the many sides of corporate sustainability. The projects were interesting and expected for the level of knowledge the class offers.

I would say that I came in not knowing a ton of these skills, so compared to some I learned a bit. I know those more experienced in business skills felt like they learned a little less. Definitely enjoyed the different and overarching perspectives. 

I got most of what I expected. I wish the cases had a little bit more to do with the course than what I ultimately got, but what will be will be.
This course aligned with my expectations well.

Pretty much lined up with my expectations. A bit more basic on some content than I had hoped, especially on the policy implications of business decisions in the contemporary political atmosphere. I had expected more guidance from the instructional staff on the assignments and the group project.

The classes touched upon many relevant and interesting topics and themes, however in my view we did not go into a deep discussion on much of the topics. 
I found that the course did not develop a particular set if skills, but an overall understanding of the role of sustainability for the private sector.
I believe it aligned quite well with my expectation
I expected the class to have more practical application, rather being steeped in theory.
Not well
Fairly well
I had high expectations for this class and this class provided me with a lot insights into the inner workings and decision-making of corporations
I liked the content but believe that there were opportunities to go deeper into each topic.

The course mostly aligned with my expectations. At times, I felt like we didn't spend enough time going deep on any topics, and instead received general overviews on a wide range of topics. This has both its advantages (learning about a range of sustainability concepts) and disadvantages (not feeling like an "expert" in any of the concepts).
Aligned with my expectations.

Strengths: Dan and Marian complement each other well. We got a good overview of some imporant concepts. It seemed particularly useful in exposing some of the students to a range of topics they had never considered before. 

Weaknesses: I was not one of the students who benefited from broad exposure, as I was already familiar with most of the subject matter and hoping to dive deeper. The material we covered was high-level and super theoretical. We did not go into enough detail on specific cases. Course organization was poor, even though this course has been offered several times before. Overall, the weaknesses vastly outweighed the strengths.

The strength is that there is a client project we got to help with outside of class. However, I think the setting of the project isn't the most ideal. The expectations from the course for the project didn't really align with the clients, and it was difficult to balance expectations from two sides.

The weakness is breadth of the topics that this class tried to cover. It's too broad.

Strength: lectures in the first half of the semester

Weakness: lectures in the second half of the semester

The study cases were the biggest strength; also the final projects were a strength. I think we could have spent a little less time in how to "sell" the sustainability strategies to stakeholder and more on how to actually design them (Supply chain, BoP, CSV, etc). Also at the beginning there was not much feedback on the grades of the study cases, which was improved by the end of the course but the feedback did not come in a timely way (i.e. having the feedback before the next study case was due).

In general the class environment was a little more tense than the regular FES class. Which can be a product of the classroom distribution, the fact that as an SOM class it was a little more competititve or the fact that some times one of the professors didn't let the students finish their questions.

Strengths: Foundation of business and environment.

Weakness: Depended too much on Professor Esty's works.

The course instructors have plenty of firsthand experience with the subject and are able to apply their knowledge to current examples of business-related environmental topics. However, many of the lectures were repetitive and common sense by the end of the semester. The course could have been strengthened by using a wider variety of examples in the class discussions and diving more into the ethics of environmental-related business decisions. In addition, the professors could have given us more thorough feedback on our assignments and final projects.
Update reading list. Instead of assigning hundreds of pages a week, pick selections from the readings as to what is the most important or influential.

1. The lectures are very repetitive. 
2. the interactions between lecturers is awkward, stilted, and sometimes downright unfriendly. This was especially evident in the midterm exam, where all of the questions came from one lecturer's lectures (Dan's) and none from the other instructor's lectures (Marian's). This was a shame as Marian's lectures were very interesting. 
3. Honestly, the main thing this course needs is a total overhaul with updated information from people who have actually worked in CSR in the last twenty years. Most of the class readings were stale and felt largely out of touch with CSR today. 
4. A number of times in this course, the instructors stopped class compelling and interesting class discussions. This has to stop as the people in the class often had more interesting things to say than the profs.

Strengths: Good case studies for environmental and business problems. Green to gold is good, (but also a weakness, class should supplement the readings, not be a repeat of the book throughout the entire semester...). 


Weaknesses: The class is extremely basic and very repetitive. The class teaches to the student with the least experience, leaving anyone with working knowledge of environmental / business issues in a slow moving class that doesn't teach to new ideas. 

Improvements: More new content please. Also, please teach to students with experience, or offer an advanced class.
The first couple of weeks are very insightful. But afterwards it became a rehashing of the same few concepts.

Strengths:
- Large breadth of knowledge
- Projects were practical and interesting
- Interim deadlines for project were appreciated
- Speakers were very interesting! It would have been great to even have more.
- Lots of great case studies to examine

Weaknesses:
- Grading seemed arbitrary and I never really knew what was expected of me for the assignments throughout the semester
- More in class activities or small group discussions would have been appreciated, a little too much lecture
- Some readings seemed a little out dated, some updating would be helpful

More focus on some of the cases! We put a lot of work into them and then don't really use them.

Also: we have a midterm and project and the essays. It's a lot of work, which is fine, but maybe look at cutting back on one or the expectations of the client project.

The final project presentation rubric seemed to focus on the slides themselves, not the overall presentation when it did not take into account volume, diction, pace, word choice, and flow.  We received a lot of comments on our power point picture selection--yet learning power point was not covered in the class.  It seemed unusual to grade an oral presentation mostly on the presentation aid and not the presentation itself.

Overall great course and I loved the range of topics. Three criticisms though. 1. A bit too basic on some topics that the students are really invested in. For example, about a third of the class went to the COP meeting in Bonn, so obviously everone is pretty keyed in on these topics, but the actual lectures relating to them were very prosaic and backward-looking. 2. We could have really gained from having more discussion of NEGATIVE cases too, businesses that tried and failed in this ESG space, such as Clorox, Chipotle, Volkswagen, Solyndra, etc. Too much focus in the lectures readings and assignments on the success stories, plus framing ambivalent stories to make them appear to be true successes. We could have learned a lot from looking at companies that try and fail to meet their goals. 3. Course organization issues surrounding assignment grading and TAs. there were three TAs in the course but it took forever to get anything graded. This meant that we were done with the second and third homeworks before we got any idea if our approach was correct, because we still hadnt gotten graded on the first. One of the TAs didnt actually have time to sit in on the course, so her grading was super harsh because she had no idea what we were actually learning. And how can there be three TAs and none of them are ever holding office hours?? Also, the assignment topics were completely detached from the course material in almost every respect, with only the most cursory attempt to address the content or expectations. Really a missed opportunity to use the assignments to complement our learning.

- The course was interesting, and a survey of the challenges of incorporating sustainability into business
- The assignments were graded very late, and had poor or no feedback. It would have been helpful to receive the grade and constructive feedback in time to be able to improve and learn from our previous assignments. Since we received the grades after all four of the assignments were handed in there was no room to know how we were doing or on what we should be improving.
- The communication for assignments, deadlines, differences between deliverables for final project, format and content expected,  etc could be improved.
- It would have been valuable for our TA to have attended our final presentation and received feedback on the presentation to be able to incorporate it to our final project.
- The team project evaluations were very binary, just regarding quantity and quality of work, leaving out space to comment on other important group team dynamics that can affect teamwork.

The strengths are the professor lectures, the homework exercises, the readings, and Marian's power-points. The weaknesses were the strict limitation to discussion. Students expressed interest in discussing the reading and homework assignments, but discussion was cut-off. I believe this restricted our education as it prevented students from a deeper level of examination. 

Another limitation was that many of the business examples or case studies were repeated (about Whole Foods and Interface carpet) and were relatively old. It would have been better to have more current examples.

More clearly articulate the long-term goals and expectations with client projects at the start of the semester. There seemed to be some surprises for some of the teams regarding meetings with Dan/Marian and meetings with TFs.

The TAs were not great
Dan's lectures did not add to the readings
Material and ideas covered was good
Poor class culture and dynamic
The client assignment was great, I'd recommend making this a larger focus of the class.

Very bland reading. Courses were for the most part very broad so I can't say I learned much that I didn't already know. It was kind of like "it is very important for you to build a metrics strategy for your company" and then there was no explanation of how to do an effective one for different types of companies.
please make the final project clear before the second to last week of class. We had no idea what the actual deliverable was until then.

One major weakness was that a LOT of the material was clearly recycled from previous semesters, which usually isn't an issue, however it was apparent that the material had been recycled so many times that a lot of it was extremely dated. This is especially true for the homework case studies.

Also, feedback and grades for the homework assignments was EXTREMELY late. Homework feedback should be returned before the subsequent homework assignment so that issues/deficiencies can be corrected and not repeated.
The instructors provided a lot of great discussion points for an engaging class.

I thought the wide swath of topics was incredible. I definitively learned how to implement a sustainability strategy. I also really enjoyed the writing assignments which required an deep dive into some very interesting case studies. I would like to have discussed the case studies more in class, perhaps using the case studies as a lens to uncovering the class themes as opposed to going down an outline of topics. I also thought the teachers could have challenged the students more - it seemed pretty easy to skirt by without participating too much. I would consider taking out some topics on policy and sustainability investing - simply acknowledging that both ESG and global climate negotiations would have been enough. But devoting an entire lecture, equating each topic with supply chain management or other key principles, does not seem to add up.

Didn't receive feedback from TAs for a long time, so was not sure how I was doing or how to improve.

Good introduction to important concepts at the nexus of business and sustainability.

Enjoyed the dynamic between Marian and Dan - both brought great insight and experience to the classroom and had informative lectures. There were several times during the semester when the class got into a lively discussion and had to be cut off for the sake of time. Perhaps it would be worth considering adding a 1-hour discussion section for the class each week, where students could continue the debates, share their sustainability experiences from the real world, or use the time for collaborating on class assignments. 

Very much enjoyed my group project, though I know other groups had challenges with their clients or group mates.

Areas for improvement: could reference the readings in class more (not just "Green to Gold"--we were assigned plenty of other material that was informative and engaging and never discussed). When class discussions get out of hand, you gotta monitor that--and not just to cut women off when they're talking. I felt that the class kept cycling through to the same few themes (when can sustainability command a premium? how do we make a business case for sustainability?? shareholders and stakeholders and social responsibility--what are we to do???) without much development or even any especially convincing or relevant case studies. So, a greater sense of direction and building towards specific insights would have been helpful. Finally, a more thoughtfully-spaced timeline for assignments coupled with *timely feedback* on our submissions would have greatly enhanced student learning. Just realized there's no spot to evaluate the TF's here, so doubling back here to double down on that point--TFs were not helpful.

Strengths: occasionally, the class discussions would be informative and stimulating.

The strengths were the consistency of the strategic framework, derived from Prof Esty's book, as well as the complementing perspectives of Prof Chertow and Prof Esty. Prof Chertows more technical focus was valuable. It could be be strengthened through modernization. Most of the low-hanging fruit of CSR efforts have already been accomplished and understanding how to go green in a world in which green is the norm is now more important.
Dan and Marian offer a nice contrast of personalities that make for a informative learning environment.
Don't take this course if you've ever covered basic concepts of business strategy. And even if you haven't covered those concepts, it still is not worth it. Take a real SOM elective instead.
It's a survey class for students who want a preliminary understanding of what's going on in this field.

I would tell them that it is useful to get acquainted with the terms and kind of conversation you would expect in a corporate environment especially if you do not come from a business / marketing background, but not to expect to get a full grasp of the technical skills on how to be sustainable.
If you're interested in business and environment, you should take this class. Even if you have some background, it was good to learn the academic side of it.

As someone who hasn't worked in the private sector before, this class helped me understand the business perspective on environmental issues. If you already have experience with business related environmental initiatives, the course will probably be fairly basic for you. Overall I'm glad I took the class.
Expect to be bored. Most of this is common sense and seemed more like an undergraduate or even an AP level course.
If you have any CSR experience or knowledge, don't take this course.

An ok intro class for someone who wants a taste of the business / environment world. This is not a good class for any MEM, even one just starting the program, rather it is a good class for an MF or MESC who wants a taste of what "business" is like.

If you are considering a career in corporate sustainability and do not have a ton of experience in it yet, this course is great for you. If you have experience, this class would bore you. Get ahead on your project and meet with your professor/TA earlier rather than later to ensure you have enough time to get through all the research. The deadlines sneak up on you!

Expect a lot of work, and prepare for that. You learn a good deal, but if you're expecting a business course that gives you hard skills this isn't it. It's more of an introduction and overview. If you get a good client project and aren't business oriented, then this is good. If you are business oriented, this may be too shallow for you.
I would not recommend taking this class if the student does not like group work.
Generally a good course with interesting materials, but don't be too sad if you don't make "the cut" to get in.
Make sure you manage expectations for the final project among your team-members so that the workload is fair. Do the reading as it really enhances your learning.
Not worth the hype and stress people place on it during the application process
If you have little experience in corporate environmentalism, this is a good introductory class. If you have ever worked in corporate sustainability, you will find this class too slow and redundant.
Don't bother
If you would like a solid introduction/overview of corporate sustainability, this is a great class.
Be willing to speak up in class and ask questions. Challenge other students on their assumptions and statements.
A strong foundational class for someone looking to go into corporate sustainability, but additional classes/experiences are definitely necessary to gain deeper expertise on the class topics.
It's an overrated class. If you do take it, remember that it absolutely is what you make of it--dive into your readings and your project and maybe you'll come away having learned something.
Make sure to bring in the class readings during discussions.
